abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Water Sector
            Consolidation Project for Guyana were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: reform programs such as this that are
            crucial to the performance of investments, require long term
            engagement. The project benefited from a more than 10 year
            Bank engagement in the sector through the previous
            investment project and the extended period of engagement in
            developing the reform agenda. This ensured a well designed
            project grounded on well developed institutional and
            regulatory reform. The long term and productive involvement
            of the government on the water sector reform also enabled
            high government and ownership at the time of appraisal which
            was able to be sustained during implementation. Even if the
            Government decided to give the management contract an early
            termination, it remained engaged in dialogue with the main
            donors and Guyana Water Incorporated (GWI) and there was
            high support at the highest levels for the agreed turnaround
            plan which proved invaluable to sustaining the improvements
            achieved and maintaining the principles of the reforms
            throughout this crucial time in the development of the
            sector, even if the management contract tool for GWI was
            discarded by the Government at the time.

            : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Water Sector
            Consolidation Project is to support the achievement of
            sustainable universal access to safe and affordable water
            for the population of Guyana, especially the poor. The
            extension is being requested to enable the completion of the
            main works under the project and to measure after completion
            the resulting improvements of the level of service.
            Principally the construction of three water treatment
            plants, which has experienced delays due to a combination of
            factors, namely initial delays in arranging the required
            subcontracting and liquidity issues from the main
            contractor, needs to be completed. Construction is now
            around 70 percent complete and is forecasted to be completed
            by September 2010 at the present rate of implementation
            progress. Project implementation was delayed by the
            termination of a contract for well drilling and another for
            transmission main setup. The new contract for well drilling
            to complete the remaining works is currently being
            negotiated for signature and is expected to be completed in
            four months. Six additional months following the completion
            of the works will be necessary to measure the improvements
            of the level of service in the project areas and evaluate
            the overall project achievement. The change is the extension
            of the closing date of the project by 12 months from its
            current closing date of March 31st, 2010, to March 31, 2011.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Water Sector Consolidation Project
            aims to support the achievement of sustainable universal
            access to safe and affordable water for the population of
            Guyana, especially the poor. The project consist of the
            following components: Component 1) will finance the
            following three subprojects: Anna Regina area water supply
            system in Division 1 of Guyana Water Incorporated (GWI);
            Parika area water supply system in Division 2 of GWI; and
            Rosignol area water supply system in Division 4. Component
            2) will finance staff, consultant services and equipment to
            strengthen the capacity of GWI and its Asset Development
            Team to execute, supervise and monitor the results of the
            Project. Component 3) will finance technical assistance
            architecture around the management contract to bring the
            needed specialized skills and expertise to support GWI.
            Component 4) will finance minor capital works targeted at
            the distribution systems and small equipment repairs and
            replacements, household connection replacements, and other
            minor investments.

repnme.cdata!:
Guyana - Water Sector Consolidation Project
            : Environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Guyana Water Sector Consolidation
            Project Environmental Guidelines for Construction Projects
            and Environmental Assessment provides contractors with an
            efficient means of complying with Environmental Impact
            Assessment (EIA) and Environmental Management Plan (EMP)
            requirements for projects in the water sector.  The
            guidelines lay out preliminary screening, basic
            environmental and social considerations, environmental and
            social guidelines, implementation, and the reporting format.
            The guidelines then detail environmental screening
            checklists for the major project construction divisions,
            also noting potential negative impacts for each division of
            the project.  Volume 2 is comprised of the Corporate
            Environmental Guidelines for Guyana Water Incorporated
            (GWI).  The corporate guidelines are composed of three
            sections; 1. GWI's mandate and environmental and social
            responsibilities; 2. GWI' s environmental and social
            guiding principles; 3. GWI employees' roles and
            responsibilities.  The guidelines note that GWI's
            mandate is to supply water to the public and its
            responsibilities follow pertinent stipulations of the
            constitution of Guyana, the Environmental Protection Act of
            1996, the National Development Strategy; the Guyana Poverty
            Reduction Strategy of 2001, and the Millennium Development
            Goals of 2000.  Its environmental and social guiding
            principles are based on playing a significant role in
            Guyana's efforts to improve its environmental and
            social situation, and in particular improving health and
            reducing poverty.
